PostValue.explanation: This post synthesises an established and practically important medical idea (nociplastic/neuroplastic pain) and points to scalable, low‑cost interventions (education, exposure-style therapy, apps, PRT) that could substantially reduce chronic suffering and healthcare costs. For the EA/rationalist community it is moderately important — relevant to global health, mental‑health funding, and high‑ROI intervention searches but not foundational to core longtermist or AI priorities. For general humanity it is high importance: chronic pain is extremely common, current care is often ineffective, and wider uptake of these approaches could produce large welfare and economic gains (though uncertainties remain about scope, optimal protocols, and not over-attributing all pain to neuroplastic causes).

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) You overstate how common/nearly-universal neuroplastic (nociplastic/central sensitization) pain is. The claim that it may be “the single most common cause of chronic pain” is a large, non-obvious claim and currently speculative. Actionable fix: soften language (e.g. "may contribute to a large fraction of chronic pain cases for some conditions") and add precise qualifiers — specify which conditions have stronger vs weaker evidence. Replace emotive phrasing with point estimates or ranges where possible, and cite systematic reviews or guideline statements (IASP, Cochrane reviews, high-quality meta-analyses) rather than single papers or popular books to support prevalence claims.

2) Clarify and distinguish terminology, and add stronger diagnostic guardrails. You use "neuroplastic pain," "nociplastic pain," and "central sensitization" somewhat interchangeably, which will confuse clinicians and informed readers. Actionable fix: include a brief, explicit definitions section that maps these terms to each other and to nociceptive/neuropathic pain, and state their overlaps and limits. Add a short, prioritized differential-diagnosis checklist and red-flag symptoms (e.g. unexplained weight loss, fever, progressive neurological deficit, night pain unrelieved by position, systemic inflammatory signs) with a recommendation to pursue appropriate medical workup before concluding a pain is primarily nociplastic. This prevents the post from being read as discouraging necessary medical evaluation.

3) Balance anecdote/popular-source enthusiasm with critical appraisal of the evidence and limitations of treatments. Your personal story and links to books/apps are useful, but readers need a clearer account of the strength and limits of interventions (PRT, somatic tracking, Curable, education). Actionable fix: summarize the key RCT(s) (sample size, inclusion criteria, primary outcomes, follow-up length, effect sizes, and main limitations), note null/negative findings or gaps (generalizability, risk of selection/publication bias), and avoid using Amazon/book pages as evidence. Explicitly state potential harms/risks of applying these methods (e.g. delaying diagnosis, worsening anxiety in some patients) and recommend how readers should integrate these options with standard care (e.g. "consider PNE/PRT alongside medical assessment; consult a clinician if red flags present; use licensed therapists for guided exposure-based work").

Small editorial suggestions: move the long personal narrative to an appendix or shorten it so the evidence and guidance stand out; replace some casual wording ("it's not all in your head") with more precise phrasing; and add a short recommended reading/citation list limited to high-quality reviews and guidelines to improve credibility without lengthening the post much.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback targets several substantive weaknesses that could mislead readers or embarrass the author if pointed out: overstating prevalence, conflating important technical terms, and not giving clear diagnostic red flags or limits of the evidence. These are critical but fixable changes that won’t require a large rewrite—soften claims, add a brief definitions/differential section with red flags, and summarize key RCTs/guidelines instead of popular sources. Implementing these would materially improve accuracy and safety of the post.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: SoerenMind appears to be a pseudonymous or low-profile online handle with no identifiable presence in EA/rationalist publications, talks, or widely-cited work, and no notable public recognition outside small online contexts.

PostClarity.explanation: Well-structured and easy to follow overall: clear headings, a concise list of key claims, supporting evidence and links, a helpful personal case study, and practical resources/treatments. The main argument (neuroplastic pain is common and treatable) is presented compellingly with citations, but the post is long and occasionally repetitive, contains a few typos/awkward phrases and some jargon/assumptions that could confuse non‑specialist readers. Tightening the prose, fixing minor errors, and adding brief lay definitions for technical terms would make it near‑perfect.

PostNovelty.explanation: For an EA/lesswrong-style readership this is mostly a well‑synthesised presentation of ideas they've probably already encountered (predictive processing, fear‑pain cycle, nociplastic pain, and prior LW/EA posts). The post mainly assembles recent clinical evidence and treatment references rather than proposing a brand‑new mechanism, so it is only modestly novel to that audience. For the general educated public the core claims are substantially more novel: the idea that much chronic pain is centrally 'learned' (nociplastic), that therapists can reverse it with large effect sizes (e.g. PRT), and that many doctors may not recognise this yet—these points are fairly new to mainstream awareness. The strongest novel elements are the emphasis that neuroplastic pain may be a leading cause of chronic pain and the practical, evidence‑backed treatment framing; those claims are plausible but still somewhat contested, which I noted in the score.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post gives a coherent, plausible mechanistic account (fear‑pain cycle / predictive processing), correctly cites established developments (e.g. WHO/IASP recognition of nociplastic pain, central sensitization literature) and references at least one RCT (PRT) and other mainstream sources. The argument structure is logical and grounded in known pain science. Weaknesses: The author sometimes overgeneralizes (e.g. that learned pain may be the single most common cause of chronic pain) and conflates related but distinct concepts (nociplastic pain, central sensitization, psychogenic explanations). Evidence is a mix of strong markers and weaker popular sources (books, apps, anecdotes) with limited discussion of heterogeneity across pain conditions, replication limits of recent RCTs, and alternative biomedical explanations. Potential confirmation and selection biases (personal success, selective citations) are not fully addressed. Overall, the thesis is well supported that neuroplastic mechanisms are important and underrecognized in chronic pain, but claims about prevalence and the universality of psychological unlearning as a cure are somewhat overstated given current evidence.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Overall the post’s core empirical claims are well grounded: (a) altered central pain processing (central sensitization / nociplastic or “neuroplastic” pain) is a well-established mechanism and accepted in major pain literature and classification schemes; (b) nociplastic/central sensitization features are documented across many chronic conditions (low back pain, fibromyalgia, IBS, pelvic pain, osteoarthritis subgroups, headaches, etc.); (c) psychological/education-based treatments (pain neuroscience education, CBT, and newer Pain Reprocessing Therapy (PRT)) have RCT evidence of benefit, and PRT produced a large effect in a high-quality RCT for chronic back pain. However, some claims are overstated or need nuance: the WHO/ICD-11 adoption relates to a new ICD-11 category of “chronic primary pain” (2019/ICD‑11 rollout) and the IASP introduced the mechanistic term “nociplastic” (2017) — so the post’s wording that “WHO added ‘nociplastic pain’ in 2019” is imprecise; evidence that neuroplastic pain is the single most common cause of chronic pain is plausible in some contexts (e.g., much low back pain is nonspecific) but not proven — prevalence/mechanistic attribution varies by condition and individual; and generalization of PRT’s very large effect beyond the studied chronic back pain sample requires replication. The claims about imaging over-interpretation and asymptomatic structural findings are supported by systematic reviews. Evidence linking nociplastic mechanisms to long‑COVID, chronic fatigue, dizziness and nausea is emerging but currently preliminary.
sources: Ashar YK et al., Effect of Pain Reprocessing Therapy vs Placebo and Usual Care for Patients With Chronic Back Pain: a randomized clinical trial, JAMA Psychiatry (open‑access full text). PMC article summarizing 66% pain-free at post‑treatment and Hedges'g ≈ 1.14. (Ashar et al., 2021/2022). — https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8482298/

IASP / ICD‑11 chronic pain classification and related papers (IASP task force; 'Chronic pain as a symptom or a disease: the IASP Classification of Chronic Pain for ICD‑11', PAIN 2019) — describes 'chronic primary pain' and the IASP/ICD‑11 approach. — https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30586067/ and https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ (IASP pages)

Systematic review of imaging features of spinal degeneration in asymptomatic populations (Brinjikji et al.), AJNR 2014/2015 — shows high prevalence of disc degeneration/bulge/protrusion in asymptomatic people (e.g., ~37% disc degeneration at age 20 in pooled estimates). — https://www.ajnr.org/content/36/4/811.full

WHO fact sheet on low back pain (2023) — states non‑specific (no clear structural cause) low back pain is the most common presentation (~80–90% non‑specific). — https://www.who.int/news-room/fact-sheets/detail/low-back-pain

Reviews on central sensitization / nociplastic pain (e.g., Kennedy et al. / Nijs et al. / 'Central Sensitization and Pain: Pathophysiologic and Clinical Insights', and 'Nociplastic pain and central sensitization in patients with chronic pain conditions: a terminology update for clinicians') — summarize mechanisms and that central sensitization/nociplastic features occur across many conditions. — https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10716881/ and https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10314229/

Meta‑analyses and systematic reviews on Pain Neuroscience Education (PNE) and CBT for chronic pain — show moderate evidence for benefit (PNE and CBT reduce pain, kinesiophobia and improve function with small–moderate pooled effects). Examples: PNE meta‑analyses (2022–2024) and CBT meta‑analyses for chronic low back/neck pain. — (examples) https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35587171/ ; https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35345623/

Curable app — published/posted RCT evidence and company summary of an independent RCT (digital PNE/skills program) — demonstrates digital programs with PNE+ components can help some chronic pain populations (trial details in public sources). — https://www.curablehealth.com/science/thomson-study-curable-efficacy

Reviews/papers on post‑COVID / long COVID and nociplastic features (phenotyping post‑COVID pain as nociceptive/neuropathic/nociplastic): emerging evidence that a subgroup of post‑COVID patients show central sensitization/nociplastic features, but data are preliminary. — https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9599440/ and related reviews

Mayo Clinic materials on central sensitization — describes central sensitization symptoms beyond pain (fatigue, dizziness, nausea) and clinical rehabilitation approaches. — https://mcpress.mayoclinic.org/living-well/what-is-central-sensitization-and-how-does-it-relate-to-pain/ and https://www.mayoclinic.org/departments-centers/pain-rehabilitation-center
